qLWnN0PF50BlSOe2v7PQfA.text: The dim sum at this place is fantastic!  The bao, soup dumplings and shumai are created and cooked to perfection, and the side dishes (especially the pea shoots and sweet potato leaves) are a nice compliment.  The Paragon Mall location is ideal for breaking up a day of compulsive shopping.  It's often packed and queues can be long, but service never suffers.  It can get pricey as it takes ordering several items in order to fill your appetite, but it's worth it.

Uc0yh1lbFL-rp7QB18iXbA.text: This is largely in the running for last meal on earth. If you're actually reading this review trying to figure if you should go then you've obviously never been. The service is standard, there's always a wait but the food is to die for. I love the truffle xiao long bao. Do yourself a favor and go....and eat a lot.

oOBNoKt6Zat6N5zQbMm7KA.text: Says it's open till 11, woman ignored us for like 5 minutes. Finally acknowledge and said rudely that they close at 9:30 it was 9:31. Bad serviceOk so we went back and the food was amazing and service was great. Upgraded to 4 Star.

2CIhgyprwtbTGRRjbb0Qwg.text: What makes this Din Tai Fung special is that they have a special menu that is only available at the Paragon location. I quite liked the fried yam on the special menu.The normal is excellent as well. You can't go wrong with staples such as Xiao Long Bao. You can even have xiao long bao with truffles if you feel like being fancy. I also like the chili crab bao, as well as all the dumplings here. The fried rice and fried vegetables are good too, I am a huge fan of the dou miao. This location is pretty big. There is usually a wait but the lines move quickly.If you have never been to Din Tai Fung, you are missing out!

j0PpUBgFn4mRwyTlZsFG0A.text: Chanced upon DTF and decided to join the queue. We were given an order sheet while waiting for a table, how efficient I thought to myself. The hostess would then call out your number and read back what you just ordered. Service is better than THW. Free flow jasmine tea. The pork chop was good and the infamous SLB is not oily.After you're done, you get the tab and proceed to the cashier to pay.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

uImnExMxKpzvWykctsnOxA.text: This was my first Din Tai Fung experience, but it won't be my last!  This one is located in the basement of the Paragon Mall.  I thought the crowds lingering outside were daunting, but they run things very efficiently and we didn't wait more than 20 minutes at 8pm on a Friday night.The host stand will give you a number and a menu, so you can prepare your order while you wait. There is also a window to watch the many, many chefs prepare the dumplings to order.  To my surprise, there are plenty of vegetarian options!The vegetarian dumplings were excellent, as were the special mushroom & truffle dumplings. The meat eaters loved the pork dumplings, and everyone agreed the spinach & garlic vegetable plate was also good. I really liked the yam steamed buns (kind of for dessert) but they are heavy.Service was great - food started arriving quickly and tea was constantly refilled. All said and done we paid SG$130 for 4 people and we really over-ordered.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. chefs at work
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. dumplings, dumplings everywhere...

M3MDgWmkFqpnhCiwIfZMbg.text: Din Tai Fung is a well known restaurant from Taiwan, specialising in xiaolongbao (steamed pork dumplings). It has a number of branches in Singapore with Paragon outlet as the flagship outlet in Singapore. The outlet was also one of the largest in Singapore with a private dining room. I reached the outlet just before it opened for business and could spot about 10 people waiting outside the restaurant. I was swiftly showed to a table. The staff also kindly provided me with a bag basket to put my handbag, plus a cloth to cover it. Hot tea was served without asked, and was chargeable at $1++.Steamed Custard Bun 流沙包 ($2++)The bun was served pipping hot. The skin was thin and smooth with its filling flowing out easily like lava.Steamed Assorted Bun Infused with Truffle Oil 菌菇大包 ($2++)Similar to the Steamed Custard Bun, the skin was thin. It was nicely smelled of truffle oil. The chopped mushroom filling was juicy and flavourful.Deep-fried Handmade Tofu with Water Chestnuts & Mushrooms 酥炸素豆腐 ($8.60++)Served with sweet chilli sauce.The tofu was quite crispy on the outside. Inside it was soft and different from the usual tofu. It was packed with shredded black fungus, shiitake mushrooms and water chestnuts. The black fungus and water chestnuts gave the tofu a unique crunchy texture. The mushrooms gave a earthy taste to the simple looking tofu.Steamed Layered Red Date Cakes 枣泥糕 ($4.80++ / 2 pieces)The simple looking cake had a kueh kueh texture, being sticky and chewy. It had a kind of unique sweetness.Overall the food was not bad. The tea was refilled often. Although it was just 11am, queue was already formed outside the restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

vvwqy-JxLaTK9uqzmiYHUg.text: I am not sure why most reviewers complained about the service here.Service was top notch, tea was constantly refilled. Never even half full. Every staff I encountered was polite. Din Tai Fung is very famous for their steamed pork dumplings or xiao long baos. Awarded one Michelin star and ranked as one of world's Top 10 Best Restaurants by The New York Times, the signature dumplings at Din Tai Fung consists of really juicy meat and melt in your mouth skin. Oh and each dumpling includes at least 18 folds. I have tried many such steamed pork dumplings in many restaurants and no one does it as well as Din Tai Fung.  Of cos Din Tai Fung (DTF) was also featured in Anthony Bourdain's show "Layover with Anthony Bourdain- Taipei".  Today I have also tried the Steamed Chicken Soup. It was light yet savory. The soup was supposedly simmered for a period of 6 hours to attain perfection. I have ordered many other dishes at DTF over the years but they did not leave much impression. So I would definitely stick to the steamed pork dumplings DTF is famous for and maybe the soup next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Kitchen -Staffs working hard to make those yummy dumplings
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. My lunch today - Steamed Chicken Soup
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Shredded ginger with vinegar

JselxehxrtaDPS7dwNdbiw.text: This used to be our family favourite until my daughter decided she had enough xiao long bao! Food is still good although with so many outlets, they all taste the same. Perfect casual dining and kids friendly. The chefs making the dumplings with such precision is still amazing to watch no matter how many times you've observed them.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Braised beef . It's been a while

ZUAE6aS4JiDgUscNScCYCA.text: If you're into dim sum, this may be a good option for you. It's served menu style, not as the take-what-you-like off the cart.I found it particulary odd- the cooks and servers all look like surgeons dressed for surgery-- white hats, white face masks, white smocks....We ordered some soup, different variety of dumplings and sauteed veggies.  Of the items we ordered, one was never served, one was promised and we waited an additional 30 minutes (after being told "another 5 min" several times)We particularly enjoyed the chili crab dumplings, but after waiting the extra 30 minutes, we weren't so thrilled overall.I don't know if as Americans we were put low on the priority list or if they are just sloppy in customer service. Either way, it's not great.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. The servers
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Oriental salad
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. The chefs are dressed like surgeons...

8XhaPHSEH76XTdfX4wqrBA.text: I know Din Tai Fung is a chain, so this review is for the orchard Rd location only. I was excited to try this place after hearing so many good things about it, but was pretty disappointed. We tried the chicken and veggie dumplings and the red bean bao. They were just average, nothing special about it. More disappointing was the service, however. We came in an hour before closing time and they were already rushing us along. The food took forever, and the waiters were clearly ignoring us. Also they serve everyone 'complimentary' tea, and then charge you for it after... Even for a cup of water, they'll charge you extra for it. I get that at a mamak stall, but not at a place like din tai Fung.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

3GvcR4RCxceFUrHg_59y3A.text: We had a great meal here. Such a great experience. Delicious dumplings and great noodle soups. A must!

PmTnW258iY8Nk3qgcpvwjw.text: Good food quality and it is all Very cleanYet a bit loud and the service is not perfect as the waiters get things wrong and the food is served in waves instead of at once which is unpractical Overall: mediate atmosphere; good food

uM10M77kjTAIcfz_-vg_Ag.text: It's all true. Very good. Enjoyed everything here very much. Even traveling with some US guys who are squeamish eaters we all had a great meal. Started with a cold glass noodle and tofu appetizer. Very tasty and warmed up our taste buds for more delights.  Don't miss the signature dumpling little dragon balls. Eat them as soon as they come to the table. I also loved the noodles with chicken dumplings. Great broth. And don't miss the vegetable sides. Worth it.

LGMPXWfchXaBGxlnRGvnow.text: Ding Tai FungParagon Shopping Centre - This is THE PLACE for thin-skinned Xiao Long Bao, among other delicious goodies! This original locale is spacious and comfortably appointed. It has 2 show-kitchens; EXCELLENT service.- Yes, as always, there is a line, but well worth the wait! OUR EXPERIENCE:- Our 2 local friends treated my wife and me to a very nice Xiao Long Bao feast here on a Wed afternoon! As expected, there was a long waiting line. But, the restaurant managed the line nicely and orderly. The area outside of the restaurant was quite pleasant and it was nice to see the kitchen staff in action through the large glass windows, while waiting anyway.  It took us less than 20min wait to get our table. The dining area is more spacious than I thought, with a neat and comfortable setting. We had 5 orders of Xiao Long Baos (- 3  with pork/truffle filling; 1 with Crabmeat; 1 with Vegie filling); plus 2 side fishes. Total ~S$80; all scrumptious!  The service was excellent: - Our orders were brought out piping hot; tea cups and water glasses kept full throughout; empty dishes promptly cleared away; wait staff pleasant and helpful.My wife and I like the setting and service in this branch better than those in Taipei and Los Angeles. The quality and variety of dishes are typical of Din Tai Fong fame, however. After such a fabulous experience, our friends then told us that there were 7+ DTF branches in Singapore! Oh boy,  I envy those LUCKY Singapore people! Peterskis3, Jan 2013

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Glass-windowed show kitchens

esxFn-WYXLOPEH3JyOizwQ.text: Always been overrated but I still love this place! I think Paragon branch is the best I have tried so far. The soup dumpling is tastier and food portion is a little bit bigger in general. Hence, although this place is always crowded regardless the timing, it's worth the wait! I can't get enough of soup dumplings! Any other huge fan of soup dumpling out there, care enough to share some underrated place for similar dish to me in Singapore? Hit me up! However, no matter which branch of DTF you are at, try ordering their Earl Grey Lemon Tea! It's like the best of both worlds.... The earl grey tea is pleasantly strong and the lemon taste makes it fresh!

qiAWsttXMsMxOo-QS3Y9Mg.text: It is my occasional place for dinner whenever I crave for fried rice pork chop. Yes, you heard me. The pork chop here is delicious! Fried rice that comes with crumbly eggs are tasty as well. Other than this dish, I normally just head to Paradise Dynasty for the xiao long bao & noodles with pork broth. Not to digress, DTF is always packed and have long queues for dinner. Hence, be prepared to queue.

VewCxRbQIHZZW0TwrktGlg.text: The food is great but the service is poor. No smiles on the waiting staff except for one. I came here consecutively for two days. What a disparity. The day before yesterday, there was a service review and I guess that was the main reason for everyone being on their best behavior forward...

XAhm_FEhN0YeAWUm6gj-QA.text: I was there for an early lunch today and it was already getting packed with diners (we are looking at 11.30 am on a Monday). Even though not all the tables were taken up, we still had to wait for about 5 minutes. 2 groups of diners were ahead of us. Service was good. We were warned the xlb and other dishes would be about 10-15 minutes wait, and only the "xiao cai" would be served immediately. But the xlb came within 10 minutes. I like that. Warn the customers and then serve the food earlier than expected, making it a good experience. Our tea was topped up very often without us having to ask. It had been quite some time (probably a couple of years or longer) since I last dined at the Paragon outlet and it had expanded since then. There were more tables available and I guessed people do get seated quickly despite the perennial long lines during dinner time. That was always daunting and explained why I hardly dined there. The xlb was still as good. Thin skin with a flavorful soup, enough to fill my spoon, and yummy meat. The fried rice was not as good as remembered though. It used to be really fragrant and just made you want more. Today's version was a bit wet, the rice stuck together and was quite a disappointment. The dumplings in vinegar and chili oil were average, mainly due to the thicker skin, so they were more chewy. I would say focus on the xlb and xiao cai, the others would be quite secondary.

eXnYns12QsOCDCnlny4r7Q.text: Had the worst experience dining here. Some of our orders came as soon as we sat down whilst the rest came oout only One and a half hour later! Dumplings were soggy and tasteless. Complained to the manager, but he just stood there and said "ok" then left and never came back. Came here with a high expectation but disappointed in every possible way

IHNJXvFcOEZiRYsjdN8MQA.text: Whenever i feel like easy fast lunch in orchard i go to this place. Nice dimsum, cheap, clean and decent place. Kids love it too. Come earlier, as its long queue most of the time when its lunch or dinner time. But no worry its goes fast.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

CqLTRR7chMh5T4PvppHaRA.text: A friend and I met with our children at Din Tai Fung tonight.  We were seated rather quickly considering the crowd. We ordered a lot of dumplings, spinach, and dates. Our food was delivered timely and it was delicious. There is lots of room for improvement in the service department at Din Tai Fung. My friend and I ordered a bottle of wine to split. The waitress brought us the bottle and two glasses and just set it on the table and left. Fortunately it was a screw cap so we could manage to pour our glasses ourselves, but needless to say that is a training issue. We also had to ask for water six times. Yes, you read that correctly, SIX times. Our children were thirsty, we wanted water and we asked for it six times. It was finally brought to our table. The food is very tasty, but the service is lacking.
